Minor update to my Notepad++ macros.
- Ctrl+1: Uppercase checker skipped strings with apostrophe. Fixed that.
- Ctrl+1: Added check for rows beginning with `#`. Since that has special function, it's a good idea to prune/replace those from the data.
- Ctrl+3: Reduced false positives in the punctuation checker.
- Ctrl+4: Reduced false positives from gun calibers for punctuation checking.
- Alt+F1: Expanded the smart quote replacer to also get rid of trailing spaces etc around the quotes in one go.

Style is generally meant to go into the context. Need to generate a poem in middle of a story? Just add `[ Style: poem ]` and it should generate one that fits the story.

As for `[ Style: ]` placement - ATTG is always first. So: ```[ Author: ; Title: ; Tags: ; Genre: ]
[ Style: ]```
If you're planning to publish something and want to keep track of them, use `##Chapter 1` etc instead. So the AI won't see it.
As I said, don't use chapter numbering at all. Those don't exist in the data.

Well, no. It's to avoid overusing headers in training. The AI needed to learn to start the story with prose.
Would be a problem if the only way it knew how to start a story were `[ Prologue ]`, when most users have brackets banned. Hence the preamble instead. (Which should never be disabled btw, even though settings allow that...)
And `[ Prologue ]`? Weak in current models. Got pruned too heavily, I'd say. Some have been retained for future training, so it'll start working at some point.

False. But if you put in tags that contradict each other, don't expect it to work well. Definitely easier to steer with fewer tags, but there's no hard limit. (And by tags, I mean `Tags:` in ATTG.)
Chapter numbering and such? That's useless, something like `Chapter 7` doesn't mean anything when authors have anything from two to 300 chapters in their works.
As for `[ Style: ]`, that should go on its own row.
Well... Can use multiple authors, but don't expect it to do much. First two fields are weak, I usually just use Tags and Genre for my own plays.

The recent models — and by that I mostly mean Krake, though some of it made it into Euterpe — are trained to follow Attributes with high quality prose, and to apply the Attributes data into that paragraph. As such, it can be used without negative impact on the quality.

That's one issue with prose: it should be varied and verbose, otherwise the AI will start mimicking it — usually hurting the output quality.
Attributes is trained to get around that. It doesn't have heavy impact on the output style.

Avoid repetition. That's better baked into the training data itself than into lorebook entries. After all, it'll trigger repetition penalty.
...with some presets, one instance is enough to make the AI avoid it, especially if placed too far to the front. That's why it often gets colors and such wrong from LB entries. Describe someone as wearing 'black shirt, black jeans, black shoes', and it likely won't use black in output.

Depends on how good you are at writing prose. I wouldn't say that it's better on average, but some things — such as relationships, nicknames, and personality traits — are much easier to explain in the Attributes without using a lot of tokens.

Any preset with low Top-K or Randomness tend to overuse punctuation, and are likely to default to other simple, common tokens.

It's really mostly third person and preset, from what I've seen. Writing descriptive prose is overplayed, as eventually retrying gets the same results with right preset. I've never had issues with getting Krake to stick to descriptive when generating from blank prompts.
The second variation. But keep in mind that the TA mode cannot output `>`, so it'll keep generating _something_ past those prompts regardless of how it is trained.

As for more descriptive prose: most importantly, use third person. And secondly, switch to a preset that allows a wider variety of output, such as Ouroboros, as the default preset defaults to plain text due to how shallow the token pool is. Then — if you can't write descriptive prose yourself — just keep retrying until you get something descriptive, and keep generating from there. It'll catch on soon enough.
TA data needs to be formatted in second person to work well, so `> You do something.` for actions.

My standard procedure for a new text is to check if it needs to have the dinkuses added (modern ebooks often use graphics for paragraph breaks). Then I hit Ctrl+F2 and Alt+F2 for automated fixes, and then go through Ctrl+1 to Ctrl+4 until those run out of problems. Finish off with Alt+F1. (Because some checks work better while the smart quotes are still intact.)

Oh, and no comments about the bad regex, ok? I'm not a regex expert, and most of these were made in multiple edits without me remembering exactly what was in already. So there's some redundancy, I'm sure.

Here's my Notepad++ macros. Might be useful to someone. Main functions are keyed to Ctrl+1-4 for various problems that may need manual fixing and Ctrl+F1-F5 for other scripts.
Quick summary:
Ctrl+1: Checks for various unicode and control characters that usually need to be pruned. Also finds strings of uppercase that may need to be replaced. Can find false positives. Just skip down a row and continue if that happens.
Ctrl+2: Locates common keyphrases for fore- and afterwords. These should usually be pruned.
Ctrl+3: Finds punctuation-related problems. 
Ctrl+4: Finds common spacing problems, such as various null-space characters that are impossible to spot normally.
Ctrl+F1: Converts the next UPPERCASE block. Best used right after Ctrl+1 finds one.
Ctrl+F2: Trims blank rows and does some other fixes that can be automated, such as replacing `\r\n` with `\n`.
Ctrl+F3: Adds the LitRPG dash.
Ctrl+F4: Adds en space, used for quotations, signs, letters, and other indirect prose.
Ctrl+F5: Adds em space, used for poetry and lyrics.
Ctrl+Numpad *: Quick bracketing for chapter titles.
Alt+F1: Replaces the smart quotes (“” & ‘’) with simple (" & '). The former are not used in the dataset, so these should always be replaced.
Alt+F2: Fixes the spacing for ellipses (such as `. . .` to `...`). The ones that can be automatically handled, anyway.

```
----
Yrthwood
Type: forest
Geography:```

Adjacent, stood sentinels of the Goddess's guard, members of her court, and fantastic beings that might not be real.
Azhriaz stared up into the curious sky. She was clothed in deep red, and in her beauty. It was enough.```

Ann Maxwell: ```Off to one side of the room was a transparent column surrounding an interior garden bright with turquoise zamay. When Ryth walked near, the tall flowers trembled and hummed and stroked their soft petals across the unfeeling column wall, asking. Ryth stopped, fingertips reaching and remembering a smoldering fall of m'zamay across his hands. But before he could find the entrance to the garden, he saw Kayle sitting just beyond the reach of sunlight, staring at the zamay with unseeing eyes. He was wearing a Carifil psitran around his forehead, but his mind was no further away than a rainbow insect flitting inside the clear column.``` Lord Dunsany: ```And evening settled down, a huge grey canvas waiting for sombre pictures; a setting for all the dark tales of the world, haunted forever a grizzly place was haunted ever, in any century, in any land; but not by mere ghosts from all those thousands of graves and half-buried bodies and sepulchral shell-holes; haunted by things huger and more disastrous than that; haunted by wailing ambitions, under the stars or moon, drifting across the rubbish that once was villages, which strews the lonely plain; the lost ambitions of two Emperors and a Sultan wailing from wind to wind and whimpering for dominion of the world.```

Vance: ```The Elder Isles had known the coming and going of many peoples: Pharesmians, blue-eyed Evadnioi, Pelasgians with their maenad priestesses, Danaans, Lydians, Phoenicians, Etruscans, Greeks, Celts from Gaul, Ska from Norway by way of Ireland, Romans, Celts from Ireland and a few Sea Goths. The wash of so many peoples had left behind a complex detritus: ruined strongholds; graves and tombs; steles carved with cryptic glyphs: songs, dances, turns of speech, fragments of dialect, place-names; ceremonies of purport now forgotten, but with lingering flavor. There were dozens of cults and religions, diverse except that, in every case, a caste of priests interceded between laity and divinity. At Ys, steps cut into the stone led down into the ocean to the Temple of Atlante; each month in the dark of the moon priests descended the steps by midnight, to emerge at dawn wearing garlands of sea flowers. On Dascinet, certain tribes were guided in their rites by cracks in sacred stones, which none but the priests could read. On Scola, the adjacent island, worshippers of the god Nyrene poured flasks of their own blood into each of four sacred rivers; the truly devout sometimes bled themselves pale. On Troicinet, the rituals of life and death were conducted in temples dedicated to the earth-goddess Gaea. Celts had wandered everywhere across the Elder Isles, leaving behind not only place names, but Druid sacrifices in sacred groves, and the 'March of the Trees' during Beltane. Etruscan priests consecrated their androgynous divinity Votumna with ceremonies repulsive and often horrid, while the Danaans introduced the more wholesome Aryan pantheon. With the Romans came Mithraism, Christianity, Parsh, the worship of Zoroaster, and a dozen other similar sects. In due course, Irish monks founded a Christian monastery on Whanish Isle, near Dahaut below Avallon, which ultimately suffered the same fate as Lindisfarne far to the north, off the coast of Britain.```

Can't help with the main topic about copying the formatting. Chris would know.
But yes, as far as telepathy goes, there's three styles that are commonly used in novels: _italics_, `<text>`, and `:text:`.
The dataset is plaintext, which means that all italics, bolding etc got lost in conversion. Telepathy was standardized to `<text>`. (And I've had to manually convert italics to brackets in hundreds of books, as it can't be automated because authors tend to use italics for other things...)
Anyway, yeah, use those for telepathy. `*text*` is standardized for sound effects, might throw the AI off if you use it for telepathy.
As for the AI understanding italics etc: unfortunately not, as like I said, it was trained in plaintext and doesn't know what to do with those. There's no token for italics, bolding, etc as far as I know.

Slash is mainly used in the data in the following ways:
1.  Unspaced `/` is used as a joiner ('wolf/sheep hybrid')
2. Spaced ` / ` is rare, and tends to be used to either separate poem lines in spoken dialogue, or as an 'or' symbol (instead of `|`).
Neither usage is fitting for Traits style lists, and it is likely that commas would work equally well - if not better.
Many numbers (such as ' nineteen') are actually single token even if written out.
They'd likely find it equally useful if they used commas.
The AI does just fine without slashes. Not like you need to tell it what abrasive etc mean.
Should be noted that there's absolutely nothing in the dataset that supports that kind of method.
It does make Attributes a bit stronger, but isn't required.

`----` is like `***`, but used for data entries.
I don't shill it much because it's kind of leaky. It's a good idea to ban it if you use it in lore.

Presets with high rep penalty and shallow token pool tend to quickly drop out of lists and chat style; that's where Ouroboros differs compared to many of the official Euterpe v2 presets.
For chat and QA, the rep penalty needs to be low enough to repeat the character names (or `Q`/`A`), and `:`, `\n`, etc for short sentences, but chat also requires large token pool so it doesn't just end up with one character monologuing. While for lists, formatting such as `,` or `-` quickly run into rep penalty issues on some presets.

`Ctrl + 2`, you'll need to disable the existing hotkey in N++'s Hotkey Mapper (used for `2nd Style` by default.)
Performs following functions:
- Replaces (most of) chapter numbers with `***`.
- Consolidates `* * *` etc into `***`.
- Replaces `\r\n` with `\n`.
- Removes empty rows.
- Removes trailing and leading spaces.
- May do some other stuff that I can't remember.

I suppose I should post the N++ macros I use for quick checks. Sorry about the shitty regex. I made these to work, not to look good. Didn't think that I'd be sharing these someday.
Notes:
- These'll need to be manually inserted into N++'s _shortcuts.xml_, check the contents to see which section goes where. Make backups of the shortcuts file first. Close N++, insert these, and relaunch.
- These will replace the default Ctrl + 1 to 4 hotkeys.
- `Ctrl + 1`: Finds common unicode issues, one issue per press.
- `Ctrl + 2`: Finds common blocks that need pruning, such as fore- and afterword. (Occasional false positives for `Part`, `Chapter` etc that appear within the actual prose.)
- `Ctrl + 3`: Finds punctuation issues.
- `Ctrl + 4`: Finds some of the spacing issues (extra spaces, missing spaces, etc.)
(I have other macros, but they have various small quirks; don't feel like sharing those right now.)
Works in some presets, but can run into repetition penalty issues with ones that have stricter penalty.
I don't use AN much, it tends to be too strong. Instead I use either Memory, or edit stage directions directly into the output.
Chances are that something like `(Description follows)` would work as well in Euterpe, due to that style being used in transcripts.
It already says init, but sure, I'll clarify that a bit.
Memory, at the very top. It has same effect as `⁂` (it initializes the story), so never put it in AN. If placed in AN, the AI will ignore most of what's before that row, causing memory issues.

**Title:** Video Games
**Description:** Another test module that I might as well publish. Was trained on a random collection of video gaming data, back when the training had issues, to see if it was working right. 49.5K steps, trained at 100%. (Yeah, a lot of stuff went into this.)
Not sure what you can with this, but here's a few uses:
- Check what the AI knows about various games, by using a `Game: (name)` prompt.
- Generate summaries and reviews for games that _don't_ exist, using same prompt as above with a made up title.
- Generate weird crossovers. For instance, I had Kratos (God of War) appearing as a Spartan (Halo) in one quick play.
**Loss:** 2.69, decent for such a varied mix.
**Tags:** video games, retro games
Sample: ```Game: No Man's Sky``````Genre: Space Exploration Simulator
Release Date: August 9, 2016
Developer: Hello Games
Publisher: Sony Interactive Entertainment
Format: PS4/PC (tested)
Rating: ★★★☆
No Man's Sky may not be the space exploration game players were hoping for. It is, however, a very pretty sandbox—and, in places, it can be surprisingly compelling.
The universe has been described as "infinite" and with good reason. After the launch of the game in 2016, many players were underwhelmed by its seemingly empty expanses; some even considered it to be a scam. In reality, those huge numbers are an effect of how the game generates planets and other celestial bodies. It does this in batches via procedural generation, creating new worlds that appear unique, while also ensuring that everything in the galaxy seems like it has been shaped by something other than man. The only drawback to this design is the sheer size of the cosmos, so you will have plenty of time to wonder, "Is there a point?"
It's worth noting that this game is all about discovery and not really about plot or characters. You play as a nameless avatar who begins their journey in the same way as everyone else: by stepping out into space from a planet where they started, and slowly making your way across the galaxy, gathering resources and trading them for money, which you then use to purchase bigger vessels, weapons, and upgrades.``` (...looks like Euterpe got the exact release date right somehow. <:shrug:332268181517238272> )

```The cuckoo went to a king's court and said, 'I'll give you a good song if you give me the princess.'
'Yes,' said the king.```

```A hunter lived in a deep forest where he hunted birds, beasts and fish. One day he came across some firewood lying about in the woods. He cut up one of the logs and carried it home to cook his supper. Then he was so pleased with himself that he took off his hunting hat and danced about before the fireplace.
"Look at me, look at me," he shouted. "I have found firewood for my cooking."
When darkness fell and the hunter went to bed, he set his bed on fire and lay down near the flames. When he had fallen asleep, he dreamt that the devil appeared before him, shouting: "Fire-bringer, fire-bringer! Give me a fire!"
The hunter woke up and realized that he had caused all the misfortune he now experienced. He quickly extinguished the flames and felt relieved. From that day forth he never again played around with fire.```

**Title:** Weird Fiction
**Description:** Trained on variety of weird fiction: bizarro, surreal, weird west, new weird, and so on. Turned out to be more coherent than I expected. Still somewhat unpredictable, and can be quite gory, with body horror, etc.
**Steps:** 14009
**Loss:** 2.79, trained at around 35% of total of 76 books.
**Tags:** weird fiction, bizarro, surreal, body horror
**Samples, empty prompts with no retries:** ```"Well, now that we're here, you should probably fill me in." The King looked around at the empty streets, still full of trash but otherwise unremarkable. "Where is everybody?"
"As far as I know," the Man in Black answered, "there's no one left in town. There was a fight between the Vampires and the Witches, apparently. Neither side has been able to hold on since then." He looked up at the sky again. It had begun to get dark and the clouds were rolling back in, revealing that night was approaching faster than it should be.
"Why would anyone do this?"
The Man in Black shrugged. "Who knows? We've got some sort of… messiah trying to clean up whatever he sees as problems in the world today. We're not sure if he's the good guy or the bad guy, but we don't have any reason to think he's going to stop until every Witch and Vampire on the planet is dead." He shrugged. "I'm really not a fan of this whole mess."
"Messiah?" the King repeated slowly. The words didn't sit well with him. "What makes you say that?"
The man frowned. "It's just… weird how much like… an angel he looks. I mean, they're all over the place these days. But this one… Well, it's not even a person. He's just some kind of… cloud… or something. It's crazy, but there are times when he makes people feel things… It's almost like he can make people believe in him. So maybe that's what it is. Maybe this whole mess is just the result of this one guy who is actually messing with everybody's head."``````(Numbly, I follow the man's orders. His words echo in my mind, even when I'm not speaking to him.)
"I saw you there," he says, "when it happened. In the crowd that day. And I thought of you then, because of what I could see." He stares into a bowl of water in the palm of his hand. The bowl has an almost circular bulge, like a pearl, and he opens it slowly.
The water spills out and I can see within it dozens upon dozens of tiny black holes. The man looks up from the bowl. He is wearing a blue robe with gold embroidery, and he wears nothing else. His chest is bare.
His eyes are golden, and they gleam in the sunlight coming through the window. It seems as if the room's light illuminates them more than the sun's rays. The eyes seem to be everywhere at once, watching me, observing me.``````Capella, the desert's red-dawn, and Capella's mother. A ship sails across a black ocean of stars, the crew rowing in silence to avoid waking the creature that lurks below. She is the size of an entire planet: her oceans are so large she cannot even see their ends. Her shores are made of mountains that have been eroded by winds and rains into stone, and where they do not stand out from the black earth she has spread her continents as far as they can stretch. Here's a N++ macro that I've been using for those, in case anyone needs it: ```        <Macro name="Replace uppercase" Ctrl="yes" Alt="no" Shift="no" Key="112">
            <Action type="3" message="1700" wParam="0" lParam="0" sParam="" />
            <Action type="3" message="1601" wParam="0" lParam="0" sParam="^(?!.?(([A-Z])[—-]\2.?[a-z]|A [A-Z][a-z]|O\.?K.?.?.?[a-z]|PS[ .]))(.?[A-Z][^a-z]?[^a-z]?[^a-z]?[^a-z]?[^a-z]){2,}(?= |$| I |[.?!].{1,4}[a-z])" />
            <Action type="3" message="1625" wParam="0" lParam="2" sParam="" />
            <Action type="3" message="1702" wParam="0" lParam="770" sParam="" />
            <Action type="3" message="1701" wParam="0" lParam="1" sParam="" />
            <Action type="0" message="2306" wParam="0" lParam="0" sParam="" />
            <Action type="0" message="2454" wParam="0" lParam="0" sParam="" />
            <Action type="2" message="0" wParam="42069" lParam="0" sParam="" />
            <Action type="0" message="2453" wParam="0" lParam="0" sParam="" />
        </Macro>``` Goes inside <Macros> in _shortcuts.xml_.
Not fully automated, but better than nothing. Press `Ctrl + F1` to convert the next instance of upper case into proper case.
Needs manual oversight so it doesn't mess up shouting etc (`Ctrl-Z` to undo bad conversion), and proper nouns need to be capitalized manually.

Tosses out 1.00 - TFS-value of tokens from the bottom end of the pool (lowest probability).
For instance, `TFS: 0,95` prunes bottom 5% (in combined token probabilities), etc.

I'd limit the usage of square brackets to these four:
**1.** The `[ Author: ; Title: ; Tags: ; Genre: ]` init block, as the very first row of the context (easiest to just put it first in Memory). `Author` and `Title` can be omitted. ATTG is heavily associated with a new story, so keep it at the top if you don't want the AI to have long-term memory issues. Proper nouns are in uppercase, everything else in lowercase.  Example: `[ Tags: London, 1820s, dragons; Genre: steampunk, drama ]`
**2.** Setting and switching scenes: `[ London, 1821 ]`, `[ Woodstock, 1969, 22:30 ]`, `[ New York, 1935, Night Club ]`, `[ Monday, 8:00 A.M. ]`, and so on. These can be used anywhere, even in Author's Note.
**3.** Switching between character viewpoints: `[ John ]`, `[ Batman ]`, etc. Won't work if the AI doesn't recognize it as a name. Can also be used in first person to help the AI keep track of the protagonist.
**4.** When something leaks from AN/Memory/LB without the brackets. But that shouldn't happen in Euterpe/Krake anyway, so this is rarely if ever needed.

Note: For these uses, the brackets should always be padded with space at the beginning and at the end of the text. Unspaced brackets have different usage, mostly appearing in footnotes and clarifications.

You can also use them like chapter titles (`[ An Unexpected Quest ]`, `[ The End of Many Things ]`, `[ Into the Wastes ]`, `[ Time Loop (3rd Restart) ]`, etc.), though the results are unpredictable. `[ Epilogue ]` is one of the rare cases where this has a consistent effect.
Feel free to experiment with other uses, but beware of the placebo effect. Except for the above uses, you're likely to get better results without the brackets.
Euterpe should be able to handle most things even without []s, often better.

Euterpe is trained to use two styles for lists: `-` and `•`.

Disabling all of those settings gets you a maximum pool of tokens with everything in it, which is most creative but can output stupid things. (Generally, tokens with <0.5 probability are bad. You end up with things like `The capital of Finland is Finland.`)
The other settings manipulate how _many_ possibilities there are.
Simplified: let's say that there are ten possibilities. With minimum randomness, the top one is 100%. With max randomness, they're all 10%.
Within limits. Strict nucleus/TFS can easily make it so that there's only one token left, so there's nothing left for randomness to change.

Low randomness vs High randomness, in practice. With low, all you're seeing is unicorns. With high, it could be anything in the pool.

'Randomness' seems easier to understand than 'Temperature'.
Think of a wilderness encounter, for instance. With low randomness it'll likely pick from the top creature tokens, because those have high probability. In essence, you'll keep running into same few encounters. But with high ~~Temp~~ Randomness, it flattens and 'rarer' tokens are more likely to be selected. It becomes more random.

There are two common standards for telepathy in published works: italics and angle brackets.
Italics is much more common, but as markdown isn't available in _.txt_ format those get lost in conversion. Which resulted in AI getting confused about what's going on. So replacing them with the other type seemed like a good idea. It was either that, or drop those books altogether.
Should work, as long as it's in the middle.
Quotes are spoken, <>s are thoughts. Don't combine them. Unless the character is actually speaking _and_ telepathically communicating simultaneously.

There is no reason to convert module material from single quotes to double. It's a complete waste of time, as the AI understands that both signify 'dialogue that goes between these'. They can use them interchangeably, and can adopt whichever style you use in the prompt.

When they are simplified, they are converted to `"` for double and `'` for single, which is exactly what was done in the finetune. Not only are those only a single token compared to three, they're far easier to type on most systems.
Vast majority of literature uses the curly quotes. That applies to both single and double. US tends to use double, UK (and its old colonies) tends to use single.
This again? Single quotes are fine. Just make sure to replace the fancy ones (`‘` and `’`) with `'`.
`[ Tags: D&D ]` should do the trick. `[ Tags: Forgotten Realms ]` definitely will, but dunno if that's the setting you want.

This formatter has issues. I wouldn't recommend it.
```str = str.replaceAll(/ +([,!])/g, "$1"); // remove whitespace preceding a comma or bang``` ...may _seem_ safe, but occasionally there are things where even that should be kept: ```- I barely had time to write ? on my board
- Cylon bowed deeply, causing a golden ! to appear over his head.
- There are 26 Latin alphabet characters, plus ? (question mark) and ! (exclamation mark).```
Whereas this...
```str = str.replaceAll(/^[^a-z0-9]+$/gm, "***"); // replace fully-non-alphanumeric lines with chapter breaks``` is more problematic. This causes misfires in about half of the works that I checked. It erases everything from lines like `"I—"` (making dialogue out of sync, causing the AI to associate speech styles with wrong characters), AI/robot-style dialogue (`YOU SEE THIS, RIGHT?` - don't even think about running this on Terry Pratchett), shouting (`"GODDAMN!"`), newspaper headlines, sign text, etc. Not only you lose those, but also end up with way too many `***`s.

Not a lot. `"Stuff . . . and things."` was common, which gets automatically cleaned to `"Stuff... and things."`
So periods or ellipses should always be followed by space. Except in cases like `...?`.
Except we really don't want to make the AI start outputting text after periods.Like this.
Not proper usage of ellipses, but far too common (especially in fanfiction and light novels) to do anything about. If we started to manually fix those, we'd spend the rest of our lives on that.

What about them? There's too many different cases to list them all. Generally the space should be left if it precedes a new sentence (unless at beginning of a new row), but removed in cases like `... "`, `... ?`, etc.
Logit bias, which I just mentioned. Can work either way. Reduce or increase.
Can't be automatically replaced due to differing usages. Empty spaces at the end of the rows get stripped, of course.
We've normalized it to `…` or `...`. Anything longer than three gets pruned down. `......` -> `...`, etc.

There's no reason to replace  `…`, they're single token and less likely to cause problems than `...` which occasionally get followed by trash characters, or more ellipses.

If it were up to me, we wouldn't replace the 'fancy' quotes either. Having different characters for starting and ending the quote would be useful. Such as with logit bias, to make dialogue less common by reducing the instances of `“`.
Whereas when those are converted to `"`, you can't do the same without having the side effect of characters making long monologues once they finally start talking.

If only authors used _italics_ only for telepathy and internal dialogue... But most of them (so far all that I've seen) combine that with regular use of italics, and sound effects.
So by mass-replacing <em>, <i> etc, you end up with:
- '_Why_ did _I buy that?_' -> `<Why> did <I buy that?>`
- "Why _did_ you buy that?' -> `"Why <did> you buy that?"`
- 'There was a loud _crash_' -> `There was a loud <crash>`
Additionally, the italics spacing is often off, resulting in a lot of `< `, ` >`,  ` >!`, etc with automatic conversion.

What I usually do is replace those in Calibre, then manually check the results once converted to txt. But it takes a lot of work per book. Some authors, such as Marc Secchia, use those 4000+ times per book.

There's no reason to ever try to convert a PDF into _txt_, unless there's nothing else available. Which is often the case with book scans -- but expect those to be extremely tricky to convert.

Yep. PDF is an image format, not text. So it's poorly suited for conversions. It _might_ OCR right if you're lucky, but single compressed pixel or a speck of dust can throw it off. Especially with things such as I/l/i.

**Title**: LitRPGs
**Description:** Trained on fantasy LitRPG books. This module was made for testing both LitRPG elements (standardized to use `─ `) and `<>` bracketing for thinking/telepathy. Seems to work ok, so I might as well publish this. Kudos to Mr.Accountant for contributing the steps. If someone tries this and runs into issues, let me know.
(As v3 lacks base LitRPG data, this'll often default to pulling skills from the D&D data. It also overuses semicolon, but that's more of an issue with the old v3 data than with the module.)
**Training**: 3120 steps, 10.1MB. Trained at around 31%, last loss 2.6179. Various authors, but I won't go into details about exactly which books were included.
Prompt `***`:
```I blinked, looking down at my hands. I had to admit that the glowing blue light was a little unnerving, but I’d grown used to it over time. The new skills were still taking some getting used to though. In fact, they were so much more than just skills. They were part of me now. My own special magic.
And the best part?
─ You are now able to summon and control magical creatures!
That was one hell of an upgrade.
The other new abilities were:
─ Improved perception (range increased by 50%)
─ Increased dexterity by 25%
─ Increased strength by 10%
─ Your mana pool has been doubled!
Those were all great improvements, but what really caught my attention was this last ability.
─ You can now cast spells without using any components or incantations!
This was amazing. It meant I could use my magic without having to worry about spending money on supplies like I always did before. And the most important thing? No chanting required! This would allow me to do things like cast fireballs with no problems. All I needed was enough mana to create the spell and then simply focus my mind on casting it. Simple as that.```
Here's what the loss looked like. Not bad, considering that the module included several authors. (Total size 10.1MB, so trained to ~31% of total.)

> I suspect this is already been suggested, but the ability to edit module names and descriptions would be really, really nice.
You can already do this by editing the module file itself. Those are at the very end. Just make sure not to accidentally tamper with the `data` section. (Backups are heavily recommended before you try to manually edit those.)

`[text]`: Metadata
`<text>`: Telepathy and other nonverbal communications (weak in v3)
`─ text`: LitRPG data blocks (not in v3; and not to be confused with a dash.)
`> text`: Occasionally used for computer output, etc. Might need to be rethought now that text adventures uses it too.
That's all standardized styles for now.
Those'll likely stop working in next versions, as they've been mostly replaced with the `─` style.

Yeah, some authors already used that in v3 content. Which is why we ended up expanding it. (Unfortunately many authors use italics instead, which gets lost in text conversions... I've had to manually add those, which is quite time-consuming.)

Right, but only in front. ```─ Slot: Legs
─ Item Class: Common
─ Item Quality: Normal```

<> is used for telepathy. After some debate with the team, we ended up preceding LitRPG-style data with `─ `. (That's 'box drawings light horizontal', which isn't used for anything else. Not to be confused with dashes though it looks the same. Having them all under same style also makes it easy to filter out: just ban the `─` token...)
But note that this didn't make it into v3, it'll only be used in the future versions.

```The snow``````had stopped, and the sky was clear. The air was cold enough to make Shard’s feathers bristle. He could feel a low-level wind blowing down from the north, pushing his wings as he flew over the wide expanse of frozen sea.
Shard glanced at Brynja beside him. She looked small against the vastness around them, her dark blue plumage standing out in stark contrast against the white snow. The breeze ruffled through her feathers, but she didn’t seem uncomfortable. Her gaze was fixed on the horizon ahead, where the sea rose up into a high cliff wall that curved around the edge of the world like an enormous wave frozen in time. "You know what this place is called?" she asked.
"No."
She nodded toward it. "Horthalgrindr. It means ‘the end of the world.’ There are stories about how if you fly too close, your wings will freeze and shatter."
"That sounds nice," Shard said wryly.```

`".` is UK style, but even most UK authors seem to use `."` nowadays, at least judging on what I've seen in the dataset.

For source formats, I'd rank them like this: azw3/mobi > epub > txt/doc/etc > pdf. The first two were generally created as digital editions, so they tend to have minimal errors. Whereas epub can be anything from digital to bad OCRs. ...and PDF's just a pain to convert to txt even if you know what you're doing.

Good txt conversions shouldn't have page numbering. Calibre, for instance, strips those.
I know that a lot of users are grabbing training material from... less than legal sources. So I'll just say this: it's usually best to get mobi/azw3 and convert that with calibre, rather than using whatever poorly formatted old `txt` conversions you find floating around.
Right. If you're not curating it, then just toss it all in and train on low %. That'll train it on random segments.
But in that case, it'd be better to just trim to to 1.5mb of handpicked segments and train 100% on that.
If you can spare time for it, and want better control over what exactly goes in, then sure.
Yep. The limit is 10k steps, as far as I know (though using that many for one module would be insane.) Not 10mb.
Going over 1500 steps will have diminishing results. Regardless of how many steps you use, the module will be 200kb and there's only so much data you can cram in that...

You don't have to train at 100%, and you generally shouldn't.
For instance, a genre model is better with something like 10mb+ of varied data and <20% steps. That way names won't get overtrained.
The Norse module was trained on 15mb of mixed viking content, and at 14% steps. Works quite well, but even at that low, it managed to fixate on certain names... ||Sigurd||

First one. Spaced `***` is a different token, one that we don't use.

It's better to leave a separator in. If you remove that, it may make the scene progression more disjointed.
With `***` as the default scene break (and filtered by default), the AI is less likely to randomly switch scenes.

1mb recommended, can work with less. Will need to experiment.

Also, since we deal a lot with poor conversions, things like checking for ` , ` are a must. The AI can easily leak bad spacing if it is left in. Stray `_` are common in poor OCRs (which often read `...` as `___`.)
And then there's more complicated stuff, such as when different speech styles (telepathy etc) are denoted with italics in the source material. Those are a pain to convert...

With three columns, this would be a pain to edit - not to mention it'd require a lot of menial work. I can almost guarantee that it wouldn't make it in. If you can find similar data on some wiki and collect that, it'd be much better.

I converted one PDF yesterday, but it took a lot of time. Basically, I duplicated the pages and redacted alternating columns (and distracting images, etc) from it. Then converted it to txt with Calibri, using max heuristics (with Line un-wrap factor at 1.00.) And then manually edited out the remaining hyphenation.
To summarize: converting epub is easy, converting pdf is a nightmare if the text is in multiple columns. (Such as in most RPG manuals.)
